title: LUS Fiber coming to Broussard and Youngsville in early 2018
text:
CLOSE Here's a breakdown of the top stories right now at theadvertiser.com. Caitlin Jacob

Buy Photo LUS Fiber. (Photo: Claire Taylor, The Advertiser )Buy Photo

By early February, some residents in Youngsville and Broussard may be customers of LUS Fiber.

For the first time, Lafayette Utilities System's Fiber telecommunications system is expanding outside the city of Lafayette to offer internet, TV and phone service in Youngsville and Broussard.

UPDATED TUESDAY: Huval says LUS will continue installing fiber in city

LUS will start installing fiber lines within a few weeks in one subdivision in Youngsville and one in Broussard, LUS Director Terry Huval said Monday. He would not disclose which subdivisions are first on the list, saying LUS Fiber is a competitive business.

"The intention is to have some presence in all cities in Lafayette Parish," he said.

LUS Fiber will take "measured steps" in expanding outside the city of Lafayette, Huval said, offering the service in new areas only if the results are positive.

"Like any business," he said, "we have to be prudent in how we expand."

Fiber lines will be installed in front of homes in select subdivisions and residents may sign up for internet, TV and phone service at the same rates paid by customers in the city of Lafayette.

More: Lafayette man admits misusing Trump's Social Security numberLUS is owned by customers in the city of Lafayette. Some might not support offering the service to residents who aren't taking the financial risk but are receiving the services at the same rates as city of Lafayette residents.

Huval said expanding its fixed assets to other areas will generate more revenue that will make the telecommunications system stronger. Some costs of the telecom system, he said, are the same no matter how many customers are served.

“When we first proposed LUS Fiber, we sought to provide Lafayette residents and businesses with the best telecommunications products and services available," Huval said in a news release.

"From the beginning, many neighboring communities asked LUS Fiber to extend its fiber lines to their communities. Now, LUS Fiber’s financial success allows us to expand outside of the Lafayette city limits. By expanding to these initial developments in Youngsville and Broussard, LUS Fiber will bring its same powerful complement of competitive services to these residents."

More: Body of abducted Shreveport woman found in St. Landry Parish lake

Mayor-President Joel Robideaux said he hopes this is the first step toward LUS Fiber expanding its offerings throughout the parish.

“Strategic growth and expansion is an important focus for any successful business enterprise. As LUS Fiber continues to extend services to newer developments within the city of Lafayette, my hope is that we will eventually have a presence in every city in Lafayette Parish. Youngsville and Broussard are the first steps toward that goal," Robideaux said.

More: As campus journalist and city judge, Saloom was an eyewitness to history

In 2006, voters in the city of Lafayette approved a proposal to issue bonds to build the LUS Fiber system. In 2007, $110.4 million in bonds were issued for the project. The first customers started receiving service in 2009.
